target_group:
Eligible Veterans must have been receiving care


at the VHA and present at moderate risk for


suicide, defined as: having endorsed recent passive


or active suicidal ideation (within the past


3 months) or a lifetime history of a suicide attempt.


Given the novel nature of the SAFER intervention,


the sample intentionally was recruited for having


moderate risk. In addition, Veterans needed to


bring in an available, consenting, and qualifying


supporting partner to participate with them. Supporting partners needed to meet at least three (two


for nonrelatives) of five inclusion criteria established by Pollak and Perlick (1991). The supporting partner had to (a) be a spouse, co-habiting


significant other or parent; (b) have more frequent


contact than others in the support network; (c) help


to support the patient financially; (d) be the one


contacted by treatment staff for emergencies; and


(e) have been involved in the patient’s treatment

target_group: outpatients aged 18 to 50 years who met the diagnostic criteria for unipolar MDD as defined in the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition (DSM-V) and confirmed by a psychiatrist using the Structured Clinical Interview for DSM (SCID-5) (American Psychiatric Association, 2015). These diagnostic criteria had to be met at the first and second visits during a 2-week screening period. Patients were required to have a significant suicidal ideation based on screening items of Beck Scale for Suicide Ideation (Miller et al., 1986) and a Beck Hopelessness Scale rating of ≥9, indicating at least moderate severity of hopelessness (Beck & Steer, 1989). Patients had to be free of psychotropic medication for at least 2 weeks prior to participation in the study.
